concept.title: The style guide cascade
concept.shortdesc: Most end-to-end authoring and publishing processes are governed by more than one style guide or reference, and the rules in different style guides take precedence over others.

conbody.p: Publishers, authors and editors rarely use one style guide or reference to control consistency. Instead, dictionaries, grammar guides, thesauruses, and other reference works are used collectively. House style guides normally nominate only variations from a public reference work. For example, a corporate style manual doesn't contain a complete standalone set of rules; it might reference spelling from the Macquarie Dictionary, language usage from Fowler's, nomenclature rules from the Microsoft Manual of Style, and other house style rules, which in turn might be built on the AGPS Style Manual.
